snippet:
Grace Street Coffee & Desserts is the perfect place to complete the Korean dining experience with something sweet.
We tried the Cookie Monster, simple but fun, and the kids loved it.
The adults went for the Basque cheesecake; not quite like the original version from Spain, but still very good.
Overall, it is a cozy spot with creative desserts and a nice atmosphere, ideal for families or anyone craving a treat after Korean BBQ

details.noise_level: Loud, but you can still talk

snippet: We went for a quick coffee break. The cortado was okay. We had their chocolate cheesecake which was a little too sweet. The atmosphere was vibrant and saw many folks order their shaved ice dessert. For us, it was an okay place. But at least they had a place to sit and eat, which is so rare in NYC.

details.noise_level: Loud, but you can still talk

snippet:
I am here with the love of my life. Bae said he wanted coffee. Nice system they have. You order at the door, grab a buzzer and have a seat then pick up towards the back.
Bae got iced viatnamese coffee. Very strong. I didn't want a beverage. Now the main item: shaved ice the mango flavor. So good it hit the spot. Enough for 2 people to share. It had fresh fruit. Now I know where to come when I'm depressed and needing a sweet little treat.

snippet: My go to spot for something sweet!! They have variety menu here. My favorite are matcha beignet, mango shaved ice and Dalgona coffee.

extracted_snippet.original: My go to spot for something sweet!! They have variety menu here. My favorite are matcha beignet, mango shaved ice and Dalgona coffee.

snippet:
Went for the Shaved Snow. Mango flavor. Was good. Big enough serving for 2 people. On the pricey side. For the beverage I went with the Vietnamese coffee. Has a very strong taste. Order at the front door. Plenty of seating inside.
1hr later I have a bad stomach ache. Must be from the coffee. It is way too strong and shouldnt be consumed with the Shaved Snow.

snippet: After lunch, stopped by at Grace Street for a sweet treat. The coffee drink was delicious - so refreshing and yummy. The dessert was also super tasty. Worth a visit!

extracted_snippet.original: After lunch, stopped by at Grace Street for a sweet treat. The coffee drink was delicious - so refreshing and yummy. The dessert was also super tasty. Worth a visit!

snippet: Grace Street Coffee and Desserts is one of my favorite places to visit with friends when we go to NYC. It’s such a cute casual cafe in Koreatown. Their Burnt Basque Cheesecake is the BEST cheesecake you may ever try. We’ve also had the beignets with matcha ice cream and the Ho-Dduk. SO AMAZING. The beignets are perfectly crisped and the matcha properly portioned to balance the earthy and sweet taste. The ho-dduk offers amazing cinnamon fluffy pastries with a sweet and creamy vanilla ice cream. It is perfect for anyone with a sweet tooth.

The beignets are perfectly crisped and the matcha properly portioned to balance the earthy and sweet taste. The ho-dduk offers amazing cinnamon fluffy pastries with a sweet and creamy vanilla ice cream. It is perfect for anyone with a sweet tooth.

snippet:
It used to be my favorite dessert spot in the city. I remember the first time I went there like 7 years ago it was cute coffee place with tasty Asian style desserts.
Unfortunately since then they’ve drastically change the interior and now it looks like Starbucks at best. They also take orders at the front so you need to know what you want before you even sit at the table. I think the reason is either new ownership or greed. The place can fit more people now, but it’s now cute and cozy spot for a date.

Food is GREAT!!! It still tastes delicious but I can see it’s changing a bit every time we go there. Portions got smaller, prices went up of course.

I would recommend this place if you like asian desserts especially shaved ice cream with fruits, but do not expect much from inside :)

snippet: We got hot coffee (not great). Boba drink might have been a better choice. The cheesecake was okay. Have had better. Not sure this was really a basque cheesecake as I’ve made one recently myself. The serving size for 1 is pretty large so come ready to share.

snippet:
The creamy richness of traditional cheesecake with the flavors of espresso, cocoa, and mascarpone cheese typical of tiramisu. The result is a decadent dessert with layers of flavor that’s sure to please any coffee lover.

The strawberry-rich cream paired with the chocolate waffle has a sweet taste that sets it apart from the rest.

The sweet and tangy flavor of Mango Madness gives your taste buds a refreshing chill.

Served over ice, Thai tea offers a unique combination of flavors that is both invigorating and satisfying. The sweetness of the condensed milk perfectly balances the boldness of the tea and the subtle spice notes, making each sip a truly enjoyable experience. It’s not just a drink, but a journey of flavors that excites the palate.

snippet: Love this place! Great coffee and desserts, especially the bingsoo. It gets busy sometimes, but service is always quick and friendly.

extracted_snippet.original: Love this place! Great coffee and desserts, especially the bingsoo. It gets busy sometimes, but service is always quick and friendly.

snippet:
As a tea and sweets lover, finding the perfect spot to enjoy a cup of joy with friends can be quite the task. However, I recently had the chance to visit Grace Street Coffee in NYC and let me tell you, it was worth the trip.

Firstly, the atmosphere was welcoming and cozy with warm lighting and sleek wooden interior. As I waited in line, I couldn't help but drool over the array of pastries and cakes displayed on those menues before me. I decided to go with one piece of everything, including shaved ices. You have to order and pay prior to enter, so make up your mind while waiting.

The cheesecake is not for everyone though.

The Lychee ices were great, really big with tons of lychee in it.  Same was with that lychee tea.

Overall, Grace Street Coffee exceeded my expectations with its beautiful atmosphere, delicious pastries, and perfectly crafted coffee and tea drinks. I will definitely be returning.

snippet:
Grace Street is a very popular dessert place located in the heart of Koreatown, serving a variety of goods such as Coffees, Milk Teas, Shaved Ice, and Waffles. We arrived around 6 PM, and it was still pretty packed, but by the time we left, the line was way out the door.

The servings are pretty large for the price, and we had to share some of the dishes to finish them. We got the Churro Waffles and the Cookie Monster. The Churro Waffles were pretty good, with a nice dip and ice cream served on the side. The dusting of churro powder wasn't overwhelming or too sweet.

The Cookie Monster shaved ice consisted of a vanilla shaved ice drizzled with chocolate syrup, and had two different toppings: oreo crumbs and mini M&M crushed pieces. The ice cream was a bit harder to scoop into with a spoon without it almost falling over, but a fork worked well to grab the pieces. It was light and fluffy, and went well with the toppings.

Service is good, they bring you to the table (if there is one available) and you may need to share the table with another group, but the dishes come out quickly and don't melt right away. Overall a great dessert spot after dinner or a casual date spot.

snippet: This place is awesome, we ordered coffee and two shaved ices- the mango madness and matcha elixir. Everything was amazing!  Fast and friendly service! Like other reviewers said, you order at the door and they give you a buzzer, walk in grab a seat and then when your order is ready you go to the bar to pick up your order and return the buzzer. Seats were easy to get because it’s constantly rotating people in and out. I highly recommend this place!

Seats were easy to get because it’s constantly rotating people in and out. I highly recommend this place!

snippet:
Grace Street is a cafe for dessert-lovers with options ranging from shaved ice, beignets, milk teas, churros, cakes and even coffee! There is something for everybody.

Located in the heart of Ktown, the place fills out quick and seems to be one of peoples favorite spots especially after dinner. Inside is spacious actually but may seem smaller because of the crowd. As covid has died down (i hope!) table sharing becomes an option now to accommodate more guests.

On this particular recent visit, we didnt order much and opted for something to share and got the matcha beignets. They were nice and puffy but soft. Despite the powdered sugar it wasnt sickeningly sweet lol the matcha powder mustve balanced the sweetness. The burnt cheesecake are a must here! Even if its to-go. They are nicely done and so delicious. The hubster loved the original meanwhile I enjoyed the matcha! Would definitely get those again!

Four stars though because i'am a huge Ube lover but the Ube coconut latte just didnt not cut it for me. Not much ube flavor that i was looking for. Otherwise the rest of the drinks and overall experience was great!

snippet:
Are you walking around in this debilitating heat and need a cool dessert but want to try something new? Grace Street is THE place to go! Especially, if you have kids - they'll love what this place has to offer.

Get off your train at Penn Station and walk a few blocks to K-town and you'll find this hype-deserving coffee and dessert shop. As soon as you walk into the small lobby, you're given menus and you pay up front. You're given a buzzer and seat yourself in the dining area. It's spacious with many tables, clean and bright. I appreciated that there are a couple of free water stations.

Now, If you're familiar with Asian cultures, you know that each one has a shaved ice dessert to help to beat the heat. Grace Street, has several "shaved snows" that give a spin on the original Korean patbingsu dessert. We ordered a couple: The "O.G" - black sesame snow (like a lighter, more delicate peanut butter flavor), mochi, red beans, strawberries, condensed milk and misugaru (powdered roasted grains give a nutty, earthy, slightly sweet taste) and the "Cookie Monster" -  sweet milk snow, M&Ms, crushed Oreos, dark chocolate drizzle, and whipped cream. I highly recommend both!

We also ordered tang hulu (chilled, skewered fruits dipped in melted sugar, creating a fun, crackly and refreshing dessert) and a "flight" of assorted mochi ice creams.

When your buzzer gives you the signal, you go to the bar at the far end of the dining area to pick up your order.

At first sight, your towering, well-accoutered shaved snows will cause your everyone's eyes to widen and all will exclaim "ooh", "wow" or "whoa.". They really are a spectacle. One snow could be  good for two people... if you really want to share. What's great is that the texture and consistency of the snow is not like Western ice-cream or gelato: although creamy, you can eat a larger volume than ice cream because these shaved snows are lighter and fluffier - you could eat the whole thing if you really wanted. I almost did, but my wife thought otherwise.

Eating the tang hulu is fun - bare your teeth and take a big bite! Spread a napkin on the table to catch the large pieces of falling sugar!

Summer of 2024 broke heat records! I don't know if we can alleviate the global temperature but you CAN alleviate your personal temperature (and even your climate-change anxiety) by visiting Grace Street!

snippet:
This place is refreshing, almost always there is a waiting line but server does a great job finding a table for you. In Manhattan there are very few coffees places that offer such a grand seating arrangements. Coffee definitely tastes better than some of the national chains (D&d or bucks).

Lil pricey otherwise it’s a good place to hangout.  Restrooms could have been cleaner . Overall , would rate about 3.5 and Would definitely recommend.
